data.additional_notes:
After playing 50+ hours, there are too many times where the game cannot hit 48fps, and in fact struggles to keep 36fps. Examples are in the open world of the continent where the camera is zoomed out far, and some of the late game cutscenes. I'm revising my rating to Silver 36 for 36/144hz.

~~My target is 48fps/144hz, although in some areas or if I need to save battery I will reduce to 36fps/144hz which is still quite smooth.~~ Settings are mostly "Low", but with Medium Textures and turn off Film Grain.

By default on Bazzite and CachyOS, the game limits the graphics settings for the Steam Deck build of the game, and looks atrocious. Use the SteamDeck=0 command to enable other graphics settings.

Would also recommend using the Decky-Framegen mod or manually installing Optiscaler to use FSR4. (As a side tangent, one of my nit-picks is that XeSS does very poorly with small particles flying in the wind, like the trash in Cyberpunk2077 or the roses and confetti at the start of Exp33. FSR4 handles these much better). In general for this game, FSR4 even on Performance still looks significantly better than XeSS quality. 

Lastly, for some easy Quality of Life fixes, download the mod "Clair Obscur Fix" and extract to your game folder. Use the launch command "WINEDLLOVERRIDES="dsound=n,b" %command%" as mentioned above. It will remove the intro videos and remove 30fps cutscene limit.
https://codeberg.org/Lyall/ClairObscurFix

data.additional_notes:
The default Steam Deck settings provide poor visual quality, but using Decky Framegen allows for FSR 3 upscaling to improve performance. While the prologue experiences several frame drops below 30 FPS, performance stabilizes to a playable 30 FPS at the start of Act 1, with only minor dips during combat.

Custom launch options are used to unlock the additional PC graphic settings.

reports_summary: Community testing shows the game feels mixed on handhelds: the Lenovo Legion Go, with low settings and FSR4, tends to sit in the mid‑30s and can struggle in wide open areas and some cutscenes when aiming for higher frame targets, while the Steam Deck, using a frame‑generation/upscaler approach, generally stabilises around 30 FPS after a few early dips. Runtime mirrors that gap — roughly 1.5–2 hours on the Legion versus about 3–3.5 hours on the Deck — and accepting a 30–36 FPS target with upscaling smooths pacing and saves battery.
